name: Palak Tofu
description: Vegan saag paneer — crispy tofu in a creamy spiced spinach sauce
notes: Press the tofu well — at least 15 minutes with a cloth or kitchen paper — for crispier results. Fresh spinach gives a brighter colour but frozen works fine if well drained.

Pantry.text: 2 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

Spices.text: 1 tsp chilli flakes, adjust to taste

steps.text: Press {tofu} with a cloth or kitchen paper for at least 15 minutes to remove excess moisture, then cut into 2 cm cubes.
Heat {oil} in a pan over high heat. Pan-fry the tofu until golden and crispy on all sides. Set aside.
In the same pan, fry the {cumin seeds} until they pop, then add {onions} and cook until deeply golden, about 10 minutes.
Add {garlic} and {ginger}, cook for 2 minutes, then add {turmeric}, {coriander powder} and {chilli flakes}. Stir well.
Add the {spinach} and let it wilt completely.
Blend everything into a smooth sauce using a hand blender.
Stir in the {coconut cream} and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the tofu back in, season with {garam masala}, {nutmeg} and {salt}, and simmer for another 5 minutes. Finish with a squeeze of {lemon} juice.

serving_suggestions: Serve with basmati rice or naan. A squeeze of lemon at the end brightens it up nicely.

name: Teriyaki Soba Noodles
description: Quick stir-fried soba noodles with mushrooms, bok choy and teriyaki sauce
notes: This comes together in 20 minutes — prep the vegetables while the water boils. If the noodles start sticking after draining, rinse them with cold water. Add teriyaki sauce gradually to taste — different brands vary in sweetness and saltiness.

Fresh.text: 3 bunches bok choy, chopped, whites and greens separated

quantity.item: bunches bok choy, chopped, whites and greens separated

Fresh.text: 1 bunch spring onions, chopped, whites and greens separated

quantity.item: bunch spring onions, chopped, whites and greens separated

Pantry.text: 80 ml teriyaki sauce, or to taste

steps.text: Bring a pot of water to a boil. While waiting, prep the vegetables. Add {soba noodles} and cook for 3–5 minutes until tender. Drain and rinse with cold water.

Meanwhile, heat {sesame oil} in a skillet over medium heat. Add {garlic}, {mushrooms}, whites of the {bok choy}, whites of the {spring onions}, {white pepper} and {red pepper flakes}. Cook for about 5 minutes until the mushrooms have released their liquid and it has cooked off.
Add 2 tablespoons of {teriyaki sauce} and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the soba noodles, greens of the {bok choy} and the rest of the {teriyaki sauce}. Toss until everything is coated and heated through.
Serve topped with remaining {spring onions} and {sesame seeds}.

name: Dal Tadka
description: Classic hearty lentil curry with a tempered spice topping
notes: Red lentils break down into a creamy texture, yellow lentils hold their shape a bit more — both work well. Lentils are easy to find in any German supermarket or Asian shop.

Pantry.text: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

steps.text: Rinse {lentils} and cook in water until soft, about 15 minutes. Drain any excess water.
In a pan, heat {oil} and fry the {cumin seeds} until they start to pop, then add {onion} and cook until golden.
Add {garlic}, {ginger}, {turmeric}, {garam masala} and {chilli}. Cook for 2 minutes, stirring often.
Add the {tomatoes} and cook for 5 minutes.
Stir in the cooked lentils and simmer together for 10 minutes.
Season with {salt} and finish with a squeeze of {lemon} juice.

serving_suggestions: Serve with basmati rice or naan bread. A dollop of coconut yoghurt and fresh coriander on top works nicely.

name: Rajma
description: Rich red kidney bean curry — even better the next day
notes: Don't rush the onions — cooking them until deep golden brown is key to the richness of the dish. Like most curries, this one is even better the next day once the flavours have had time to develop.

Pantry.text: 2 tins (400 g each) red kidney beans, drained and rinsed

quantity.item: (400 g each) red kidney beans, drained and rinsed

Pantry.text: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

Spices.text: 1/2 tsp chilli powder, adjust to taste

steps.text: Heat {oil} in a heavy-bottomed pan and fry the {cumin seeds} until they pop.
Add the {onions} and cook on medium heat for 12–15 minutes until deep golden brown.
Add {garlic} and {ginger}, cook for 2 minutes.
Add {turmeric}, {coriander powder}, {smoked paprika}, {chilli powder} and {tomato purée}. Stir well and cook for 2 minutes.
Add the {tomatoes} and cook for 8–10 minutes until the sauce thickens and the oil starts to separate slightly.
Add the {kidney beans} and {vegetable stock}, stir well, cover and simmer on low heat for 20–25 minutes.
Lightly mash a few beans with the back of a spoon to thicken the sauce further.
Season with {salt}, finish with {garam masala} and fresh {fresh coriander}.

serving_suggestions: Serve with basmati rice. A squeeze of lemon and a dollop of coconut yoghurt work well on top.

name: Galettes Bretonnes
description: Traditional Breton buckwheat crêpes with sautéed mushrooms — naturally vegan and gluten-free
author: James
notes: The batter needs at least 2 hours of resting in the fridge, ideally overnight — plan ahead. The first galette is almost always a throwaway (la galette de test!) so don't worry about it. Good buckwheat flour is key — look for farine de sarrasin or blé noir. Stack cooked galettes under a tea towel to keep them warm and pliable. Leftovers keep well in the fridge for 2–3 days; reheat in a dry pan.

Fresh.text: 200 g mixed mushrooms (chestnut, oyster, or shiitake), sliced

quantity.item: mixed mushrooms (chestnut, oyster, or shiitake), sliced

Pantry.text: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

steps.text: Sift the {buckwheat flour} into a large bowl and add the {salt}. Gradually pour in the {water} while whisking continuously until the batter is smooth and thin, like single cream. Cover and rest in the fridge for at least 2 hours, ideally overnight.
When ready to cook, check the batter consistency and add a splash of water if needed.

Heat a drizzle of {oil} in a pan over medium heat. Add the {mushrooms} and cook for 5 minutes until golden. Add the {garlic} and {thyme}, cook for another minute, then add the {soy sauce}. Stir and set aside.
Heat a large flat pan over medium-high heat. Lightly grease with {oil}.
Pour a ladleful of batter and quickly spread it as thinly as possible.
Cook for about 2 minutes until the edges lift and turn crispy. Flip and cook for 1 more minute.
Spoon the mushroom filling onto the galette, fold the edges in, sprinkle with fresh {parsley}, and serve immediately.

serving_suggestions:
Serve with a bowl of cidre breton for the full Breton experience. Other vegan filling ideas: creamy leeks with oat cream and nutmeg; ratatouille; caramelised onion and spinach with vegan cheese; roasted butternut squash with cumin, hummus, and toasted pumpkin seeds; or vegan pesto with sun-dried tomatoes, pine nuts, and rocket.

For vegetarian fillings: a fried egg with grated Comté (the classic complète); goat cheese with honey and walnuts; sautéed mushrooms with egg and Gruyère; or wilted spinach with ricotta, lemon zest, and black pepper.

name: Tofu Scramble
description: The perfect egg-free scramble — spiced with kala namak and chipotle, creamy on the inside, crispy on the outside
author: James
notes: Press the tofu for at least 24 hours to extract all the water. The drier the tofu, the better it will brown. Kala namak (Indian black salt) is the secret ingredient — it gives the scramble its eggy flavour. You can find it at Indian grocery stores or online.

Fridge.text: 120 ml full-fat oat milk (or creamy plant milk)

quantity.item: full-fat oat milk (or creamy plant milk)

steps.text: Make the eggy sauce. In a bowl, whisk together the {turmeric}, {garlic powder}, {onion powder}, {paprika}, {chipotle chile flakes}, {kala namak}, {tahini}, and {nutritional yeast}. Gradually pour in the {oat milk} and whisk until smooth.
Crumble the pressed {tofu} with your hands into chunks — not too big, not too small.

Heat a large nonstick frying pan over medium-high heat with the {olive oil}. Once hot, add the tofu and fry until lightly browned, 5 to 7 minutes. Stir occasionally but not too often to let the exterior crisp up.
Pour in the eggy sauce and continue frying until the scramble is as moist or dry as you like — pull it off the heat early for a soft, creamy scramble, or keep going for firmer, drier curds.
For extra creaminess, stir in the {plant-based yogurt} and mix through.
Taste and add a pinch {kala namak} and {black pepper} if needed.

serving_suggestions: Serve with halved cherry tomatoes, sliced cucumber, bell pepper strips, and toasted crusty bread.

name: Sesame Tantanmen Ramen
description: Creamy sesame broth with spicy tofu crumbles and fresh vegetables
author: James
notes: Tantanmen is the Japanese take on Sichuan dan dan noodles. The key is the sesame paste — use Asian sesame paste (not tahini), which is made from toasted seeds and has a much deeper flavour. If you can't find rayu (Japanese chilli oil), any chilli oil works. Press the tofu well before crumbling for crispier results.

Fridge.text: 200 g firm tofu, drained and crumbled

steps.text: Heat a drizzle of {sesame oil} in a skillet over medium heat. Add {garlic} and {ginger}, stir for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add the crumbled {tofu}, {soy sauce} (1/2 tbsp), {miso paste}, and {chilli oil}. Fry for 3 to 5 minutes, stirring often, until the tofu is golden and crispy. Set aside.
Steam or blanch the {cabbage} and {bean sprouts} for about 3 minutes until just tender. Set aside.
In a small bowl, mix the {sesame paste}, remaining {soy sauce} (1 1/2 tbsp), {rice vinegar}, 1 tsp {sesame oil}, and {rayu} into a smooth paste.
In a saucepan, heat the {soy milk} and {vegetable stock} over medium-low heat. When it starts to bubble, reduce the heat to low and whisk in the sesame paste mixture until fully dissolved.
Cook the {ramen noodles} according to the package instructions. Drain and divide between two bowls.
Pour the hot broth over the noodles. Top with the spicy tofu crumbles, steamed vegetables, {sweetcorn}, {spring onions}, {crushed peanuts}, and {sesame seeds}. Finish with extra {rayu} to taste.

serving_suggestions: Serve immediately while piping hot. For extra heat, add more rayu or a drizzle of chilli oil on top. A squeeze of lime on the side is a nice addition. If you want a richer broth, stir in an extra tablespoon of sesame paste.

name: Chilli Sin Carne
description: A hearty vegan chilli packed with beans, lentils, and spices that tastes even better the next day
notes: The cocoa powder adds a lovely depth without making it taste chocolatey. Add the chilli powder gradually and taste as you go if you're not sure about heat levels. For a smoky twist, add a finely chopped chipotle pepper or a teaspoon of chipotle paste. Freezes brilliantly in portions for easy weeknight dinners.

Pantry.text: 1 tin (400 g) kidney beans, drained and rinsed
1 tin (400 g) black beans, drained and rinsed

steps.text: Heat {olive oil} in a large pot over medium heat. Add the {onion} and cook for about 5 minutes until softened.
Add the {garlic}, {red pepper}, {yellow pepper}, {carrots}, and {celery}. Cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Stir in the {cumin}, {smoked paprika}, {chilli powder}, {ground coriander}, {oregano}, and {cayenne pepper}. Cook for 1 minute to toast the spices.
Add the {tomato puree} and stir well.
Pour in the {chopped tomatoes} and {vegetable stock}. Add the {kidney beans}, {black beans}, {red lentils}, and {sweetcorn}.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a low simmer. Cover and cook for 25 to 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the lentils are soft and the chilli has thickened.
Stir in the {cocoa powder}, squeeze in the {lime} juice, and season with {salt and pepper}.
Taste and adjust the spices as needed. Let it sit for a few minutes before serving.

serving_suggestions: Serve over rice, with baked potatoes, or with tortilla chips and guacamole. Top with vegan sour cream, fresh coriander, diced avocado, sliced spring onions, or a squeeze of lime.

name: Kale and White Bean Stew
description: A hearty, comforting stew with smoky spices, tender kale, and creamy white beans
author: James
notes: This stew actually tastes even better the next day as the flavours develop. Keeps in the fridge for 3 to 4 days and freezes well in portions for easy future meals.

Fresh.text: 120 g kale, stems removed and leaves roughly chopped

quantity.item: kale, stems removed and leaves roughly chopped

Pantry.text: 1 tin (400 g) white beans (cannellini or butter beans), drained and rinsed

quantity.item: white beans (cannellini or butter beans), drained and rinsed

Spices.text: 1/2 tsp chilli flakes (optional, adjust to taste)

steps.text: Heat the {olive oil} in a large pot over medium heat. Add the {onion}, {carrot}, and {celery}, and cook for about 5 to 7 minutes until softened.
Add the {garlic}, {smoked paprika}, {cumin}, and {chilli flakes}. Stir for about a minute until fragrant.
Pour in the {chopped tomatoes} and {vegetable broth}. Give it a good stir and bring to a simmer.
Add the {white beans} and let it simmer for about 10 minutes so the flavours come together.
Toss in the {kale} and stir it through. Let it cook for another 5 to 7 minutes until the kale is tender but still has a bit of bite.
Season with {salt}, {pepper}, and the {lemon} juice. Taste and adjust as needed.

serving_suggestions: Serve with a chunk of crusty bread for dipping. Drizzle with good olive oil and a sprinkle of nutritional yeast for a savoury, cheesy flavour.

name: French Crêpes
description: A proper French recipe, no eggs, no dairy, all delicious
author: James
notes: The resting time is important. It lets the flour fully hydrate and the gluten relax, which makes the crêpes easier to spread thinly and less likely to tear. The first crêpe is almost always a disaster. Consider it a test run and adjust the heat accordingly. La première est pour le chien! Corn starch will give slightly crispier crêpes, potato starch will give softer, more flexible ones.

Fridge.text: A little vegan butter for the pan

Pantry.text: 30 g corn starch or potato starch
2 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)
1 tbsp of vanilla extract or orange blossom water (optional, for sweet crêpes)

quantity.item: of vanilla extract or orange blossom water (optional, for sweet crêpes)

steps.text: Sift the {flour} and {starch} into a large bowl. Add the {sugar} and {salt}.
Make a well in the centre and gradually pour in the {oat milk} while whisking from the centre outward, incorporating the flour slowly. This avoids lumps.
Add the {oil} and {orange blossom water} (or {vanilla extract}) and whisk until smooth.
Add the {sparkling water} and give it a final mix.
Let the batter rest for an hour. It should have the consistency of liquid cream. If it's too thick after resting, add a splash of oat milk or water to thin it out.
Heat a crêpe pan (or flat non-stick pan) on medium-high heat. Melt a small knob of {vegan butter} on the pan.
Pour a thin layer of batter, swirling quickly to cover the whole surface.
Cook for about 1-2 minutes per side until lightly golden.
Repeat, adding a little {vegan butter} to the pan between crêpes.

serving_suggestions: Spread with Nutella (ideally a version without palm oil), lemon and sugar, or fresh fruit and whipped coconut cream. For savoury crêpes, skip the sugar and fill with sautéed mushrooms, spinach, or ratatouille.

name: Creamy One Pan Spinach Gnocchi
description: Quick and creamy one-pan gnocchi in a coconut cream sauce with sun-dried tomatoes, garlic, and spinach — completely vegan and ready in 20 minutes
author: Kimberley

Fridge.text: 2 tbsp cream cheese, vegan or regular

Pantry.text: 55 g sun-dried tomatoes, finely chopped (oil packed)
2 tbsp nutritional yeast (or finely grated parmesan)

steps.text: Warm {olive oil} and {butter} in a wide skillet over medium heat. Add {onion} and {garlic}, cook for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.

Pour in {coconut cream} and whisk in {cream cheese} until smooth. Simmer 2-3 minutes to gently reduce. Stir in {sun-dried tomatoes}, {nutritional yeast}, {Italian seasoning}, {pepper}, and a pinch of {salt}.

Add {gnocchi} and stir well. Cover and cook 3-4 minutes, stirring once or twice, until tender and the sauce is silky. If the sauce tightens too much, add splashes of {water} as needed. If it's too loose, let it bubble uncovered to thicken.
Stir in {spinach} until wilted. Mix in {lemon} juice if using. Taste and adjust seasoning.

serving_suggestions: Serve with a drizzle of oil from the sun-dried tomatoes.

name: Creamy Mushroom Soup
description: Rich and creamy mushroom soup perfect for batch cooking and freezing
author: James
notes: For a deeper, more umami flavour, add a splash of dry white wine after cooking the onions and let it reduce before adding the stock. If you have dried porcini, soak a small handful in warm water for 20 minutes, chop them up and add them along with their soaking liquid for incredible depth. The soup keeps well in the fridge for 3-4 days and also freezes beautifully.

Fresh.text: 500 g mixed mushrooms (champignon, king oyster, shiitake), sliced

quantity.item: mixed mushrooms (champignon, king oyster, shiitake), sliced

Fresh.text: 1 medium floury potato (about 150 g), peeled and cubed

steps.text: Heat {olive oil} in a large pot over medium-high heat. Add {mushrooms} and cook for about 8 minutes until they've released their liquid and turned golden brown. Set aside a small handful for garnish if you like.
Lower the heat to medium, add a little more oil if needed, and cook {onion} for about 5 minutes until soft and translucent.
Add {garlic} and {thyme}, stir for about a minute until fragrant.
Add {potato} cubes and {vegetable stock}. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for about 15 minutes, until the potato is completely tender.
Stir in {oat cream} and {soy sauce}.
Blend the soup using a stick blender until smooth and creamy. If you set some {mushrooms} aside earlier, stir them back in now for a bit of texture.
Season with {salt}, {pepper}, and a squeeze of {lemon} juice. The lemon really lifts the flavour.
Serve with fresh {parsley} on top and some crusty bread on the side.

serving_suggestions: Serve with crusty bread for dipping. Add a swirl of extra oat cream and a drizzle of truffle oil for a fancy touch. Great with a side salad for a complete meal.

name: Pain d'Épice
description: Traditional French spiced honey cake with warming spices
author: James
notes: This delicious French spice bread is best enjoyed the next day when the flavours have had time to develop. It keeps well wrapped in foil for up to a week. The spice mix typically includes cinnamon, green aniseed, star anise, nutmeg, coriander seeds, cloves and ground ginger, but you can also use a pre-made pain d'épices spice blend if available.

Fridge.text: 250 ml (1 cup) milk (or plant milk for a vegan version)

quantity.item: milk (or plant milk for a vegan version)

Pantry.text: 250 g (1-3/4 cups) plain flour (T45 / Type 405 / Tipo 00)
3 tbsp honey (or jam for a vegan version)

quantity.item: honey (or jam for a vegan version)

Spices.text: 2 tsp spice mix (cinnamon, green aniseed, star anise, grated nutmeg, coriander seeds, cloves, ground ginger)

quantity.item: spice mix (cinnamon, green aniseed, star anise, grated nutmeg, coriander seeds, cloves, ground ginger)

steps.text: Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan).
In a large bowl, mix together {brown sugar}, {flour}, {honey}, {baking soda}, {orange blossom water}, {spice mix}, and {milk} until well combined and smooth.
Pour the batter into a greased rectangular baking tin (about 20cm x 10cm).
Bake for 45 minutes, or until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean.
Let cool in the tin for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

serving_suggestions: Slice and enjoy with butter, or serve with tea or coffee. Even better the next day when the flavours have mellowed and the texture becomes more moist. Store wrapped in foil to keep fresh.

name: Creamy Pumpkin & Potato Curry
description: Warming vegan curry perfect for batch cooking and meal prep
author: James
notes: If you like a bit of heat, add a chopped chilli or some chilli flakes in step 2. A handful of spinach stirred in at the end is a nice addition. Keeps well in the fridge for 3–4 days and actually tastes even better the next day!

Fresh.text: 500 g floury potatoes, peeled and cubed

Pantry.text: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

steps.text: Heat {oil} in a large pot over medium heat. Add {onion} and cook for about 5 minutes until soft.
Add {garlic}, {ginger}, {curry paste}, {cumin}, and {turmeric}. Stir and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add {pumpkin} and {potato} cubes and stir everything together so they're coated in the spices.
Pour in {coconut milk} and {vegetable stock}. Give it a good stir and bring to a gentle boil.

Reduce the heat, cover, and let it simmer for about 20–25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until both the {pumpkin} and {potatoes} are tender. The floury {potatoes} will start to break down and thicken the sauce beautifully.
Season with {salt} and {pepper}, then serve over rice (or with naan) topped with fresh {coriander} and a squeeze of {lime}.

serving_suggestions: Serve over basmati rice or with warm naan bread. Top with fresh coriander and a squeeze of lime. Great for meal prep – portion into containers for easy weeknight dinners throughout the week.

name: Silky Smooth Hummus
description: Silky smooth hummus with the perfect creamy texture
author: James
notes: Use warm chickpeas, as they're softer and easier to blend. The ice cubes are not optional! The cold shock against the warm chickpeas aerates the hummus beautifully. Don't add olive oil to the base mixture. The tahini has plenty of fat. Olive oil goes on top when serving. The hummus keeps well in the fridge for up to 3 days.

Spices.text: Optional: pinch of cumin, paprika, sumac, or za'atar

steps.text: Cover {chickpeas} with plenty of water, add 1 teaspoon of {baking soda for soaking}, and leave overnight.

Drain and rinse the {chickpeas}. Place them in a pan with the second teaspoon of {baking soda for cooking} and stir over medium heat for a few minutes. Add enough water to cover them by a few centimeters, bring to a boil, and simmer for 20 to 40 minutes until they're really soft with no bite at all. Skim off any foam and loose skins as they cook.
Drain {chickpeas} over a bowl, saving the cooking water.

While the {chickpeas} are still warm, put them into a food processor with {tahini}, {garlic}, {lemon} juice, {ice cubes}, 2 tablespoons of the reserved chickpea water, a good pinch of {salt}, and a couple of {ice cubes}.

Blitz until smooth, then taste and adjust. You might need more {tahini}, {garlic}, {lemon}, {salt}, or chickpea water. Don't be shy about adding more {tahini}. Blitz for a few minutes at least until it's really smooth and creamy.
Transfer to a bowl, cover the surface with cling film, and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
Serve drizzled with good {olive oil} and a squeeze of {lemon}. Optionally sprinkle with {cumin}, {paprika}, {sumac}, or {za'atar} for extra flavour.

serving_suggestions: Drizzle with your best olive oil and add a squeeze of fresh lemon. Sprinkle with cumin, paprika, sumac, or za'atar. Serve with warm pita bread, fresh vegetables, or use as a sandwich spread. For the tahini, Al Arz is a great brand that's not too bitter.

name: Classic British Scones
description: Light and fluffy vegan scones perfect for afternoon tea
author: James
notes: Keep the margarine cold – this helps create a flaky texture. Don't overwork the dough, just bring it together gently. Best eaten fresh on the day, but they freeze well too. Just defrost at room temperature and reheat in a hot oven for a few minutes.

Fridge.text: 150 ml plant milk for the dough
A splash of plant milk for brushing

steps.text: Preheat the oven to 220°C / 200°C fan / Gas 7 and lightly grease a large baking tray.
Whisk together {flour}, {baking powder}, and {salt} so the raising agent is evenly distributed.
Using your fingertips, rub the cold {margarine} into the {flour} until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs.
Stir in {sugar}. Add most of the {plant milk for the dough} and mix to form a soft and slightly sticky dough. If it's a little dry, add more milk until you get the right consistency.
Turn out onto a floured work surface and knead very lightly. Pat out into a round about 2cm thick.
Use a 5cm cutter to stamp out rounds and place on the baking tray. Lightly knead together any remaining dough and stamp out more scones to use it all up.
Brush the tops with a little {plant milk for brushing}.
Bake for 12-15 minutes until well risen and golden.
Cool on a wire rack. Serve with jam and vegan butter, or vegan whipped cream if you're feeling fancy!

serving_suggestions: Serve warm with jam and vegan butter. For a traditional cream tea, add vegan whipped cream. Try adding dried fruit or a pinch of cinnamon to the dough for a twist.

name: Banana Bread
description: Moist and delicious banana bread made with simple plant-based ingredients
author: James
notes: Use very ripe bananas with lots of brown spots for the best flavour and natural sweetness. The banana bread keeps well wrapped in foil for 3-4 days at room temperature, or can be frozen for up to 3 months. For extra indulgence, fold in some chocolate chips or chopped walnuts before baking.

Pantry.text: 60 ml vegetable oil (e.g. rapeseed, sunflower, canola)

steps.text: Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan). Spray a 9×5 inch (23×13cm) loaf pan with nonstick spray, then dust with flour.
In a large mixing bowl, roughly mash {bananas}. Add {light brown sugar}, {oil}, {vanilla}, and {unsweetened plant milk}, and whisk to incorporate.
Sift in {flour}, {baking soda}, {salt}, and {cinnamon}, and use a wooden spoon to mix until just combined. Don't overmix.
Transfer the batter to your prepared pan, and top with {extra banana slices}.
Bake for about 45 minutes, then cover with foil and bake for 10-15 minutes longer, until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out with just a couple of crumbs.
Let cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before slicing.

serving_suggestions: Enjoy warm with vegan butter, or toasted the next day. Delicious for breakfast with coffee or as an afternoon snack. Try spreading with peanut butter or almond butter for extra protein.
